title: Nayyara Noor
text:
Nayyara Noor (, ) is a Pakistani <a href="playback%20singer">playback singer</a> who is considered one of <a href="South%20Asia">South Asia</a>'s popular film songs playback singer and a stage performer. She performs in the live <a href="ghazal">ghazal</a> singing concerts on <a href="Pakistan%20television">Pakistan television</a> shows or in concert halls in the country.
Early life and career.
Nayyara Noor was born on 3 November 1950 in <a href="Guwahati">Guwahati</a>, <a href="Assam">Assam</a>, northeastern <a href="India">India</a>, and spent her early childhood there. Her family and ancestors, belonging to a merchant class, were long settled in Assam having migrated from <a href="Amritsar">Amritsar</a>, in <a href="Punjab">Punjab</a>. Her father was an active member of the <a href="All-India%20Muslim%20League">All-India Muslim League</a>, and had hosted Pakistan's founding father <a href="Muhammad%20Ali%20Jinnah">Muhammad Ali Jinnah</a> during his trip to Assam before the <a href="Partition%20of%20India">partition</a> in 1947. In 1957 or 1958, Noor with her mother and siblings migrated from India to Pakistan, settling in <a href="Karachi">Karachi</a>. However, her father stayed back in Assam until 1993 to look after the family's immovable properties. As a child, Nayyara is said to have been inspired by the <a href="bhajan">bhajan</a>s of <a href="Kanan%20Devi">Kanan Devi</a> and Kamla as well as the <a href="ghazal">ghazal</a>s and <a href="thumri">thumri</a>s of <a href="Begum%20Akhtar">Begum Akhtar</a>.
Although Nayyara had no formal musical background nor formal training, she was discovered by "Professor Asrar Ahmad" at the <a href="Islamia%20College%20%28Lahore%29">Islamia College</a> in <a href="Lahore">Lahore</a> after hearing her sing for her friends and teachers at an annual dinner at the <a href="National%20College%20of%20Arts">National College of Arts</a> in <a href="Lahore">Lahore</a> in 1968. Soon thereafter, she was asked to sing for the university's <a href="Radio%20Pakistan">Radio Pakistan</a> programs.
In 1971, Nayyara made her public singing debut in Pakistani television serials and then beginning with films like "Gharana (1973)" and "Tansen". She has since sung ghazals penned by the famous poets like <a href="Mirza%20Ghalib">Ghalib</a> and <a href="Faiz%20Ahmed%20Faiz">Faiz Ahmed Faiz</a> and has performed with legends like <a href="Mehdi%20Hassan">Mehdi Hassan</a> and <a href="Ahmed%20Rushdi">Ahmed Rushdi</a>.
Awards and recognition.
She has since performed at <a href="mehfil">mehfil</a>s and <a href="mushaira">mushaira</a>s having cemented a following among ghazal lovers in Pakistan and India. Probably the most famous ghazal of hers (a form of song in Urdu poetry) was " Ae Jazba-e-Dil Gar Main Chahoon", written by <a href="Behzad%20Lucknavi">Behzad Lucknavi</a> (1900-1974), a renowned poet of Urdu naats and ghazals, scriptwriter and songwriter of <a href="Radio%20Pakistan">Radio Pakistan</a>. Nayyara Noor later won many awards for this ghazal.

During her long singing career, she has sung <a href="ghazal">ghazal</a>s, <a href="geet%20%28song%29">geet</a>, <a href="nazm">nazm</a> and national songs. Sober and shy, she has always maintained her high singing standards from the beginning. She has also recorded hundreds of songs for the Pakistani films.

Nayyara's admirers look forward to listening to her melodious voice for many years to come from her recordings. However, Nayyara Noor officially announced in 2012 that she no longer will sing professionally. After her marriage, she maintains that her primary roles have been those of a wife and a mother. She says that music has been a passion with her but never her top priority. Making money also has not been very important to her.
Personal life.
She is married to <a href="Shehryar%20Zaidi">Shehryar Zaidi</a>. Her younger son <a href="Jaffer%20Zaidi">Jaffer Zaidi</a> is the lead vocalist of "Kaavish" music band, while the elder son Naad-e-Ali has started his debut as a solo singer.
